title: China stocks tumble despite action to stop rout
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Tue, Jul 7, 2015, 08:51 BST - UK Markets close in 7 hrs 39 mins China stocks tumble despite action to stop rout By Bloomberg | Telegraph – 24 minutes ago 384,000.00 -43,000.00 
Concern is growing that China’s bid to stem a rout in the nation’s equities is failing 
Emerging-market stocks fell toward their lowest level in six months as industrial companies slid and concern grew that China’s bid to stem a rout in the nation’s equities is failing . 
China’s CRRC Corp tumbled 7.4pc to lead industrial shares lower. The Shanghai Composite Index sank 2.6pc amid a record drop in margin bets. Hong Kong’s Hang Seng China Enterprises Index headed for a bear market with a 20pc drop since May. Amorepacific Corp (KSE: 090430.KS - news ) slumped 13pc in Seoul as LIG Investment and Securities Co downgraded the stock. 
The MSCI Emerging Markets Index declined 0.7 pc to 937.20 at 1:41 a.m. in Hong Kong, its fifth day of losses. 
Traders cut 93.6bn yuan (£9.6bn) worth of share holdings purchased with borrowed money on the Shanghai exchange on Monday, the most since at least 2010. 
Chinese stocks fell on Tuesday despite official efforts to shore up slumping prices 
Euro-area leaders and finance ministers meet on Tuesday as German Chancellor Angela Merkel said “time is running out” for Greece to come up with a plan to stay in the currency union. 
“Markets remain volatile as there is no solution yet to the Greek crisis and the Chinese market stabilisation is not yet convincing for most investors,” said Attila Vajda, managing director at Singapore-based advisory firm Project Asia Research & Consulting Pte. 
Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras was given hours to come up with a plan to keep his country in the euro as citizens endure a second week of capital controls. 
Stock Valuations 
The developing-nation gauge has fallen 2.1pc this year and trades at 11.3 times projected 12-month earnings, data compiled by Bloomberg shows. The MSCI World Index has gained 1.2pc in 2015 and is valued at a multiple of 16. 
All 10 industry groups in the emerging-markets measure declined. CRRC, a Chinese rail company, sank toward the lowest level since March 17 in Hong Kong. Amorepacific, a cosmetics maker, was poised for the steepest drop on record. The stock was cut to hold from buy at LIG. The Kospi index fell 0.8pc to the lowest level since June 17. 
The Shanghai Composite Index headed for the lowest close since March 25. Technology, health-care and material shares led losses, while PetroChina Co surged 6.5pc on speculation of state fund buying. The Hang Seng China Enterprises Index slid 2.8pc. 
A flurry of measures to stabilise the market, including a pledge by state-run financial firms to buy 120 billion yuan worth of shares and a halt to initial public offerings, is failing to stop the rout that erased more than £2tn of value in less than a month. 
South Korea’s won weakened 0.4pc against the dollar, while Indonesian rupiah rose 0.4pc, the most since June 9. 
A gauge of 20 developing-nation currencies slid 0.1pc, its third day of declines. 
• Why Chinese stocks are in turmoil
